=001  807
=008  211115s1755\\\\|||g||||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$av
=100  \\$aBérard, Jean-Antoine$d1710-1772$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1684590$95483
=245  \\$aL'Art du chant
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bDessaint; Saillant; Prault; Lambert$c1755
=300  \\$a[xvi]-158-[6]-34 pages$bmusical examples
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$adedicated to Madame de Pompadour, the official chief mistress of King Louis XV from 1745 to 1751, who remained influential as court favourite until her death
=500  \\$aincludes an anatomical plate of the lungs
=500  \\$aAuthorship claimed by the Abbé Blanchet, who afterward published his "L'art, ou les principes philosophiques du chant" (Paris, 1756) as "2. édition, corrigée & augmentée." a designation that arises from the publication in 1755 of L’art du chant, dedié a Madame de Pompadour by Jean-Antoine Bérard, whom Blanchet accuses of incorporating his material. The two works certainly include many passages which are almost identical, notably the first and third chapters, ‘La voix considérée par rapport au chant’ and ‘La formation de la voix’. Blanchet in turn seems to have based much of his work upon the physician and anatomist Antoine Ferrein’s De la formation de la voix de l’homme (1741), although he refutes this imputation.
Joseph Blanchet was not a musician but a priest and, in his own words, ‘homme de lettres amateur’.

=500  \\$aconcludes with a 34-page appendix containing vocal airs by Rameau, Campra and others.
=501  \\$aTartini's 'Traité des agrémens de la musique' (1775)
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aMethod$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2250960$921402
=650  \0$aSinging$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q27939$92767
=651  \0$aFrance$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q142$9131

=700  \\$4dub$aBlanchet, Jean$d1724-1778$95482
=856  \\$uhttps://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8623287n$3Gallica
=942  \\$cBOO
=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_49_04F12A$70$8RAR$9807$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$i 04F12a$oKTS1 C1.49 04F12a$p20137728$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO

=LDR  12522 a  a2201165   4500
=001  808
=008  211115s1775\\\\|||g||||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre$hita
=100  \\$aTartini, Giuseppe$d1692-1770$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q108555$95536
=245  \\$aTraité des agrémens de la musique
=260  \\$aParis$bLa Chevardière$c1775
=300  \\$a[ii]-94-[1] pages$bmusic examples
=500  \\$aThe translator, Pietro Denis, also known as Pierre Denis, was an Italian mandolin virtuoso and teacher, and composer, who studied under Giuliano in Naples and established himself in Paris. 
=500  \\$aCited in Koopman 1985, pages 21, 79-82 ("zeer lezenswaardig")
=501  \\$aBound in with Bérard's 'L'Art du chant'
=534  \\$aItalian original text originally published in 1752-56, with French text first published in 1770
=590  \\$aContenant l'origine de la petite note, sa valeur, la manière de la placer, toutes les différentes espèces de cadences, la manière de les employer, le tremblement et le mordant, l'usage qu'on en peut faire, les modes ou agrémens naturels, les modes artificiels qui vont à l'infini, la manière de former un point d'orgue. Ouvrage original non seulement aux maitres de goût du chant, mais encore à tous les joueurs d'instrumens, et que tout bon musicien même compositeur lira avec beaucoup de plaisir.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aHolder, William$d1616-1698$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3568708$95538
=245  \\$aA Treatise of the Natural Grounds, and Principles of Harmony.$bTo which is Added, by way of Appendix: Rules for Playing a Throw-Bass;
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aLondon$bPearson$c1731
=300  \\$a[vi]-206 pages$b1 folded page, musical examples
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aGottfried (Godfrey) Keller (b. c. 1650, probably in Germany; † November 1704 in London), keyboard player and composer, is the author of a posthumously published method for basso continuo: A Compleat Method for attaining to Play a Thorough Bass upon either Organ, Harpsichord, or Theorbo-lute..... (John Cullen, 1707) 
=500  \\$aWilliam Holder was an English clergyman and music theorist of the 17th century. His most notable work was this widely known 1694 publication "A Treatise on the Natural Grounds and Principles of Harmony".
=590  \\$awith Variety of Proper Lessons, Fuges, and Examples to Explain the said Rules. Also Directions for Tuning an Harpsichord or Spinnet. By the late Mr. Godfey Keller. 
With several new Examples, which before were wanting, the better to explain some Passages in the former Impressions. The Whole Being Revis'd, and Corrected from Many Gross Mistakes in the First Publication of These Rules

=500  \\$aPhilippus Pool was the organist of the Onze-Lieve-Vrouwekerk in Leiden 1755-1759

=008  211115s1731\\\\|||gfa||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aPrelleur, Peter$d1705-1741$4aut$95540
=245  \\$aThe Modern Musick-Master or, The Universal Musician …
=260  \\$aLondon$bPrelleur$c1731
=300  \\$a[xii]-48-[iv]-48-[iv]-48-[iii]-48-[iv]-48-[iv]-48-[i]-20-4 pages$b6 folded pages, musical noatation, 6 engraved frontispieces
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aContains: "An Introduction to Singing"
=500  \\$a"Directions for Playing on the Flute"
=500  \\$a"The Newest Method for Learners on the German Flute"
=500  \\$a"Instructions upon the Hautboy"
=500  \\$a"The Art of Playing on the Violin"
=500  \\$a"The Harpsichord Illustrated and Improv'd"
=500  \\$a"A Brief History of Musick, and a Musical Dictionary"
=500  \\$aContains 8 beautiful frontispieces, engraved by I.Smith, appropriate to each part, most depicting people playing musical instruments.
=500  \\$awith 7 folding plates of instruction, fingering charts, and musical examples
=500  \\$amainly musical notation, less text
=500  \\$aPeter Prelleur was of French extraction and in early life a writing master. About 1728 he was elected organist of St. Alban, Wood Street, and shortly afterwards engaged to play the harpsichord at Goodman's Fields Theatre, which he continued to do until the suppression of the theatre under the Licensing Act in 1 737, composing also the dances and occasional music. In 1730 he published « The Modern Musick Master, or, the Universal Musician/ containing an introduction to singing, instructions for playing the flute, German flute, hautboy, violin, and harpsichord, with a brief History of Music, and a Musical Dictionary ». In 1735 he was elected the first organist of Christ Church, Spitalfields. After the closing of Goodman's Fields Theatre he was engaged at a newly opened place of entertainment in Leman Street close by, called the New Wells, for which he composed some songs, and an interlude entitled « Baucis and Philemon », containing a good overture and some pleasing songs and duets, the score of which he published. Fifteen hymn tunes by him were included in a collection of twenty-four published by one Moze, an organist, in 1758, under the title of « Divine Melody », in which he is spoken of as if then dead. 
=504  \\$aindex
=590  \\$aContaining I An Introduction to Singing ... II Directions for Playing on the Flute ... III The Newest Method for Learners on the German Flute ... IV Instructions upon the Hautboy ... V The Art of Playing on the Violin... VI The Harpsichord Illustrated and Improv'd ... A Large collection of Airs and Lessons ... With a brief history of Musick ... to which is added a musical dictionary.

=245  \\$aHet Boek der Psalmen, nevens de gezangen bij de Hervormde Kerk van Nederland in gebruik.$bmet Catechismus
=246  \1$aDe CL Psalmen Davids Geheel op Musijck-Noten Uit drie Berymingen. In den Jaare 1773 gebooren
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bPutte, van der$c1777
=300  \\$bfrontispiece engraving$a[568]-72 pages
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$afrontispiece engraving depicting David playing the harp, and alternative title "De CL Psalmen Davids Geheel op Musijck-Noten Uit drie Berymingen. In den Jaare 1773 gebooren"
=500  \\$a15C18: songbook unpaginated. Introduction with 4 Psalms set for 4 voices, and 12  canons. Bound in with paginated (72 pages) and undated "Catechismus".
=500  \\$asee also 08D03, 08F17 and 15C18 / 04F20 (identical exemplars)
=501  \\$a "Catechismus ofte Onderwysinge in de Christelyke Leere, die in de Kerken ende Schoolen der Nerderlandsche Gereformeerde Kerken geleert wordt. Mitsgaders De Belijdenisse des Geloofs, ende de Liturgie der selver Kerken, Amsterdam, van der Putte, s.d."

=500  \\$a04F24, 03I17 and 11E25 are identical, except for the size (different cuts of identical prints),  and a slightly deviant arrangement of introduction pages i-xlii
=500  \\$ain item 04F24: inserted manuscript letter from a man to his wife inserted: "Lieve Muis..."

=100  \\$aHurtado de Mendoza, Antonio$d1586-1644$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q4776699$95550
=245  \\$aQuerer por solo Querer = To Love only to Love
=260  \\$as.l.$bs.n.$cs.d.
=300  \\$a167 pages
=500  \\$aPlay, "Drammatic Romance" in 3 acts, ending with a tournament ballet for 6 ladies dressed as men
=500  \\$aMight be an incomplete part of a larger publication of 1671 (?London, Printed by William Godbid, 1670 ?)
https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo/A45225.0001.001?view=toc
=500  \\$aIncomplete? Title page, dedication, casting etc missing. Text bound in white vellum cover, named "VARIA" on the spine.
=500  \\$aTranslated into English by Sir Richard Fanshawe, afterwards ambassador at Madrid, in a posthumous volume published in 1671.
=500  \\$aCover notes in pensil and ink in different hands, including: "F. Stern 1745 / const: 1d" (published by F. Stern, first edition 1745?); "Henry Reijncke 5P 8 pence" (ex libris?)
=520  \\$aQuerer por solo querer, was published with Mendoza's consent; it is included in a volume (1623) containing his semi-official account of the performances at Aranjuez in 1622."Querer por solo querer To love only for love sake : a dramatick romance : represented at Aranjuez, before the King and Queen of Spain, to celebrate the birthday of that King, by the Meninas, which are a sett of ladies, in the nature of ladies of honour in that court, children in years, but higher in degree (being many of them daughters and heyres to grandees of Spain) than the ordinary ladies of honour, attending likewise that queen / written in Spanish by Don Antonio de Mendoza 1623 ; paraphrased in English, anno 1654 ; together with the Festivals of Aranwhez.

=100  \\$aGervasoni, Carlo$d1762-1819$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q16268404$95553
=245  \\$aNuova teoria di musica ricavata dall'odierna pratica$bossia metodo sicuro e facile in pratica per ben apprendere la musica
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aParma$bBlanchon$c1812
=300  \\$a455-[3] pages$bengraved portrait 
=500  \\$aCarlo Gervasoni (Milan, 4 November 1762-Borgo Val di Taro, 4 June 1819) was an Italian organist, violinist and composer, as well as harpsichordist, philosopher and music theorist. 
=500  \\$aEngraved portrait of the author by Giuseppe Benalea after Aquilino Bigatti
=500  \\$aTogether with Francesco Galeazzi's 'Elementi Teorico Pratici di musica' (1796; see 10C01) this essay offers an important source on sonata form theory.
=590  \\$aa cui si fanno precedere varie notizie storico-musicali

=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aWritten 1648-54, premiered 2 February 1654 in Amsterdam
=500  \\$adedicated to Emperor Ferdinand III
=500  \\$afs contains motto "Præcipitemque immani turbine adegit" and emblem "Elck zyn beurt" (a well)
=500  \\$ain a convolute 'Treurspelen, vol. 1' (c. 1700) ex libris Jan van den Arend (stamp, ms. shelfmark no. 363)
=500  \\$apossibly one of the eight reprints by De Wees, see 41A21, pages 193-195
=500  \\$aalso contains 'Moyses gezang' (p. 68f.)

=008  231025s1881\\\\|||gf|||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=059  \\$abc
=100  \\$aKornatzki, F. W. von$4aut$95580
=245  \\$aA Compendium of Thorough Bass for Self-Instruction$bexemplified on his Patent-Chord-Denoter
=260  \\$aLondon$bWeekes$c1881
=300  \\$a41 pages$e 6+38+14 cards (called" slides") to be put under the glass of the "Chord Denoter" in a cardboard pocket 
=500  \\$aCurious, late treatise on basso continuo containing a playful card system (for the amateur?) to learn everything about harmony, keys, chords, and basso continuo in a practical way
=500  \\$aThe Chord Denoter, a device developed by Kornatzki, was a painted piece of glass fixed on a little stand divided in two compartments on which the cards had to be put in order to learn continuo
=500  \\$aStamp on title page
=563  \\$aLeather bound, with gold-embossed front cover
=648  \0$a19th Century (1801-1900)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6955$920935
=650  \0$aMethod$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2250960$921402
=650  \0$aBasso continuo$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q724321$921065
=650  \0$aHarmony$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q184421$92358

=100  \\$aNorth, Roger$d1651-1734$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q354440$921443
=245  \\$aThe Life of the Right Honourable Francis North - The Life of the Right Honourable Sir Dudley North Knt. And of the Honourable and Reverend Dr. John North
=260  \\$aLondon$bWhiston$c1742$c1744
=300  \\$a[v]-333-[10] + [vii]-288-[7] pages$bmarbled endpapers, engraved frontispieces, leather bound, embossed gold & red spine, red edges
=500  \\$aJohn North was the fifth of fourteen children of Sir Dudley North, 4th Baron North. 
=500  \\$aFrancis North, 1st Baron Guilford, was the third son of Sir Dudley North, 4th Baron North. 
Like many upper-class Englishmen of his time, Fr. North was devoted to music. Less typically for his time and class he had a keen interest in musical theory (as did his brother Roger), and published a book on the subject, A Philosophical essay on musick (1677), which has been praised as "an admirably clear exposition of the physical basis of music". Francis North's musical notations have been described as the earliest known examples of synthetic phonograms.
=500  \\$aDudley North, 4th Baron North, was an English politician, who sat in the House of Commons at various times between 1628 and 1660.
=500  \\$aFrontispiece portrait engraving of Francis North by G. Vertue after David Loggan
=500  \\$aFrontispiece portrait engraving of Dudley North by G. Vertue 1743
=504  \\$acontains two indexes
=561  \\$aEx libris James S. North (Plate)
=563  \\$aLoose front cover, book contained in modern marbled cardboard box
=590  \\$aFrancis North, Baron of Guilford, Lord Keeper of the Great Seal, under King Charles II. and King James II. Wherein are inserted the Characters of Sir Mathew Hale, Sir George Jeffries, Sir Leoline Jenkins, Sidney Godolphin, and others the most eminent Lawyers and Statemen of that Time.
=590  \\$aSir Dudley North, Knt. Commissioner of the Customs, and afterwards of the Treasury to his Majesty King Charles the Second. 
=590  \\$aDr. John North, Master of Trinity College in Cambridge, and Greek Professor, Prebend of Westminster, and sometime Clerk of the Closet to the same King Charles the Second

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBlankenburg, Quirinus van$d1654-1739$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3258957$95596
=245  \\$aElementa musica$bof Niew licht tot het welverstaan van de musiec en de bas-continuo
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aThe Hague$bBerkoske$c1739
=300  \\$a2 vols. in 1 (xxix-200-[1] pages)$bengraved frontispiece, 30 illustrated plates inserted
=500  \\$aQuirinus van Blankenburg (1654-1729) was a musical prodigy who already became organist to the Remonstrantse Kerk in Rotterdam at the age of fifteen. After studies in philosophy in Leiden he worked in The Hague, serving as organist to the Nieuwe Kerk.
=500  \\$aContains a portrait of the author
=590  \\$aDoor Regelen, met Reden en bewys, gebouwd op een klare ontledinge der eerste Beginselen; Na een voorafgaande wederlegging van de dwalingen dezes tyds. Waar nevens De vinding en opkomst der Konst; De Musiec der Ouden; De Redenmaat der Klanken; De ontdekking van een Wiskunstige Cirkel, Waar in de Wet der Nature al de Toonen verdeelt; De Stelkonst; De Speeltuigen En de Grondlegging van de Zangkunst.

=041  \\$adut
=059  \\$av kbd
=100  \\$aRöhner, Johan Carl$4cmp$95599
=245  \\$aFannij door Mr. Rhijnvis Feith$bin muziek gebragt en toegewijd aan Mejuffrouwen Anna Schlingemann en Elisabeth Susanna van Hoboken
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bAllart$c1808
=300  \\$a56-20 pages$bcardboard cover, deckle edges, folded pages
=500  \\$aOriginally 'Fanny, een fragment' (1783), see also 03D01
=500  \\$aJohan Carl Röhner (1774-1837) succeeded Johan Gottlieb Nicolai as the city organist of Zwolle
=500  \\$aRhijnvis Feith (1753-1824) was a poet from Zwolle who studied law in Leiden together with Willem Bilderdijk, by whom he was influenced
=648  \0$a19th Century (1801-1900)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6955$920935
=650  \0$aSong$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7366$94164
=650  \0$aPoetry$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q482$93026
=651  \0$aZwolle (Netherlands)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q793$985
=700  \\$aFeith, Rhijnvis$d1753-1824$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1375304$4aut$95084
=942  \\$cSCO
=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C3_35_04J19$70$8RAR$9922$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C3$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$l0$oKTS1 C3.35 04J19$p20145958$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$ySCO
=999  \\$d922

=LDR  03633aad a2200337   4500
=001  923
=008  231030k17731780|||||l||\||||\00|\0\ger\d
=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$aSATB bc
=245  \\$a[Für die kunstliebenden und vaterländische Jugend  von der Musik-Gesellschaft auf der teutschen Schule in Zürich]$b1773-76; 1779-80
=260  \\$aZürich$bDeutsche Schule$c1773-76; 1779-80
=300  \\$a[50 pages]$bbound in paper, plates
=500  \\$aCollection of fragments of a larger unknown publication (paginated 483-538, with plates nr LXI, LXII, LXIV, LXVII) and another section in different page dimensions and folded pages.
=500  \\$aSee 04J21, 10B20, 11H13, 26D03, G1-027 and G1-028 for similar collections 
=500  \\$aContains 4 beautiful engravings by Johann Rudolf Holzhalb (1723-1806)
=505  \\$gDie Ankündigung der Seligkeit für die Friedfertigen Vorgestellet nach Matth. Cap.V v.9. und der  kunstliebenden Jugend verehrt von der Vereinigten Music-Gesellschaft in der Grösseren Stadt auf der Teutschen Schul in Zürich - Die Ankündigung der Seligkeit für die; welche um Christi und um der Gerechtigkeit willen geschmähet und verfolget werden. Vorgestellet nach Matth. Cap.V. v.10, 11, 12. Von der Lobl. Vereingten Music-Gesellschaft in der Grösseren Stadt auf der Teutschen Schul in Zürich - Der Frühling der Natur, Ein anmutiges und treffendes Bild der frohen Auferstehung und des immerwährenden Frühlings des ewigen Lebens.  Der  kunstliebenden Jugend verehrt von der Vereinigten Music-Gesellschaft in der Grösseren Stadt auf der Teutschen Schul in Zürich - Die Betrachtung des Winters als eine Ermunterung zur Erwegung Allmacht Gottes.  Der  kunstliebenden Jugend verehrt von der Vereinigten Music-Gesellschaft in der Grösseren Stadt auf der Teutschen Schul in Zürich - Neujahrsgeschenk für die vaterländische Jugend  von der Musik-Gesellschaft auf der teutschen Schule in Zürich
=520  \\$aIn the 17th century music in Zürich was dominated by three collegia musica: the first was ‘zum Chorherrensaal’, followed by the ‘ab dem Musiksaal’ (from 1613) and ‘zur deutschen Schule’ (from 1679). Initially they were concerned only with sacred music, but later also performed contemporary German and Italian secular music. The three societies merged in 1812 to form the Allgemeine Musikgesellschaft Zürich (AMGZ), which since 1813 has produced books on musical subjects in a series of ‘Neujahrsblättern’, the successors to a series of New Year collections of polyphonic pieces published by two of the collegia musica from 1685 and 1713 respectively.
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1754
=610  \0$aAllgemeine Musikgesellschaft Zürich (Switzerland)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2648827$921129
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aVocal music$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q685884$93319
=650  \0$aEducation$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q8434$926206
=650  \0$aReligion$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q9174$93062
=650  \0$aPoetry$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q482$93026
=650  \0$aMoral education$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25457248$93171

=008  231030i17721776|||||l||\||||\00|\0\mul\d
=041  \\$ager$alat$dger
=059  \\$aSSB
=245  \\$aMusikalische Neujahrsgedichte$n1772-74; 1776
=260  \\$aZürich$bMusiksaal$c1772-74$c1776
=300  \\$a[36 pages]$bbound in paper, plates
=500  \\$asee 04J20, 10B20, 11H13, 26D03, G1-027 and G1-028 for similar collections
=500  \\$aThe Musikgesellschaft ‘ab dem Musiksaal’ began to publish New Year's pieces in 1685
=500  \\$aCollection of fragments of a larger unknown publication (paginated 303-310 with plates nr LXXXVIII and LXXXIX) and other sections in different page dimensions
=500  \\$acontains 2 beautiful engravings by Johann Rudolf Holzhalb (1723-1806) after Johann Rudolph Schellenberg (1740-1806)
=520  \\$aIn the 17th century music in Zürich was dominated by three collegia musica: the first was ‘zum Chorherrensaal’, followed by the ‘ab dem Musiksaal’ (from 1613) and ‘zur deutschen Schule’ (from 1679). Initially they were concerned only with sacred music, but later also performed contemporary German and Italian secular music. The three societies merged in 1812 to form the Allgemeine Musikgesellschaft Zürich (AMGZ), which since 1813 has produced books on musical subjects in a series of ‘Neujahrsblättern’, the successors to a series of New Year collections of polyphonic pieces published by two of the collegia musica from 1685 and 1713 respectively.
=610  \0$aAllgemeine Musikgesellschaft Zürich (Switzerland)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2648827$921129

=008  210601s1796\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\d\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aDe Spanjaarden in Peru of de Dood van Rolla; Aballino, de Groote Bandiet; Liefde en Vaderland
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1796
=300  \\$a184-211-54 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak$v1/16
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.
=534  \\$aKotzebue's "Die Spanier in Peru, oder Rolla's Tod" was originally published in 1796. The Dutch translation premiered that very year in Amsterdam; Zschokke dramatized his novel  "Abällino, der grosse Bandit" (1793) in 1795. Its Dutch translation premiered in Amsterdam in 1796; "Liebe und Vaterland" by Ludwig Benedict Franz von Bilderbeck was first published in 1789. It's also know as "Erste Liebe" (1801).$ohttps://books.google.be/books?id=zNNqNJxynikC&printsec=frontcover&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false
=610  \0$aStadsschouwburg Amsterdam (Netherlands)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1817103$921020
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aPlay (theater)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25379$921414
=651  \0$aNetherlands$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55$9173

=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_04_05A01$70$8RAR$9939$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$i05A01$l0$oKTS1 C1.04 05A01$p20136490$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO

=LDR  02723 a  a2200337   4500
=001  940
=005  20251031151757.0
=008  210601s1797\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\d\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$a Cava van Conseugra, een offer der vrouwelyke wraak - De jonge Richelieu of De Fransche Lovelace - Volsan, of de menschenhater door tegenspoed'
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1797
=300  \\$a130-148-54 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak $v3/16
=500  \\$a"Cava von Conseugra, ein Opfer der Weiber-Rache" by Joseph Herbst premiered in 1794
=500  \\$aDuval was a French dramatist, sailor, architect, actor & theatre manager. "La Jeunesse du Duc de Richelieu, ou le Lovelace Français", he wrote together with Monvel, and premiered in 1796.
=500  \\$aThe title-page of "Volsan" suggests it may be a translation by Villenhoven of a somewhat older (anonymous) french play.
However, the two extant versions of the play - both published in Amsterdam - also suggest the opposite scenario: The Dutch version having been published in 1797 and the French as "Volsan ou le Misanthrope par Infortune" in 1798, both by J. Dòll. Since no information could be found about the author beyond references to this one play, it could be argued that he (or she) may have been a bilingual Dutch or Belgian playwright, who wrote and published the play in both languages.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aPlay (theater)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25379$921414
=651  \0$aNetherlands$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55$9173
=700  \\$4aut$aDuval, Alexandre$d1767-1842$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q767332$95613
=700  \\$4aut$aBoutet, Jacques Marie$d1745-1812$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1089209$95614
=700  \\$4aut$aHerbst, Joseph$95615
=700  \\$4aut$aVillenhoven, J. D.$95616
=765  \\$aCava von Conseugra, ein Opfer der Weiber-Rache - La Jeunesse du Duc de Richelieu, ou le Lovelace Français - Volsan ou le Misanthrope par Infortune
=856  \\$uhttps://books.google.be/books?id=w6JZAAAAcAAJ; https://books.google.be/books?id=uKJZAAAAcAAJ; https://books.google.be/books?id=wqJZAAAAcAAJ

=534  \\$aKotzebue's "Der Opfer-Tod" and "Die Versöhnung" premiered both in 1798; "Adrienne, ou Le secret de famille" by Collot premiered in the Paris "Théatre Royal" on 19 April 1790

=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aKlara van Synau- Komplimenten en wind - De schuldige echtgenoot
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1799
=300  \\$a184-163-64 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak$v6/16
=500  \\$a"Klara (Clara) von Synau. Ein Trauerspiel in 5 Aufzügen" by Christen Henrik Nielsen was published in 1797.
=500  \\$a"Komplimenten und Wind, ein Lustspiel in vier Akten" by Christian Friedrich Bretzner was published in 1796.
=500  \\$aBretzner was one of the most popular German librettists and comedy poets at the end of the 18th century. He's famous for writing the libretto to a singspiel entitled "Belmont und Constanze, oder Die Entführung aus dem Serail", produced in Berlin and adapted in 1782 by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Gottlieb Stephanie as" Die Entführung aus dem Serail". Bretzner's operetta had been composed by Johann André. Bretzner protested publicly in 1782 in the Leipziger Zeitung against the plagiarism by Mozart and his librettist Johann Gottlieb Stephanie the Younger, who reworked the text according to Mozart's ideas. One difference between the two works was that Bretzner made his end on a positive note, with Selim Bassa turning out to be Belmonte's father. Some of Bretzner's songs, such as Vivat Bacchus, became very well known through Mozart's interpretation. The fact that Bretzner published a German adaptation of Mozart's "Così fan tutte" in 1794, "Weibertreue oder die Mädchen sind von Flandern", is interpreted as a sign of reconciliation or even adoration of Mozart.

=500  \\$a"Le Mari Coupable: Comedie En Trois Actes, En Prose" by Villeneuve was published in Paris in 1794.
=500  \\$aSophie Villeneuve borrowed her husband's name (François Du Plessy, 1755-1828?)  and used several other names and pseudonyms to have her plays printed and performed.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aPlay (theater)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25379$921414
=651  \0$aNetherlands$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55$9173

=700  \\$4aut$aVilleneuve$d1755-1828$95624
=765  \\$aKlara von Synau - Komplimenten und Wind - Le Mari Coupable

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aBlanka en Henriko - De Abt de l'Epée - De Broeders
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1800
=300  \\$a115-128-138 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak $v7/16
=500  \\$a"Blanca und Enrico : Ein Trauerspiel in fünf Aufzügen" by David Friedrich Gensicke was published in 1795.
=500  \\$a"L'Abbé de l'Épée, comédie historique en 5 actes et en prose" van Jean Nicolas Bouilly was  premiered in 1799, Paris, Comédie-Française.
=500  \\$aThe dutch version seems to be translated by Samuel Iperusz. Wiselius, for a performance in the "Nederduitschen Schouwburg te Amsterdam" in 1800.
=500  \\$a"L'Abbé de l'Épée" features Charles-Michel de l'Épée (1712-1789), inventor of sign language and creator of what has now become the National Institute for Young Deaf People in France. A great figure and benefactor of humanity, the abbot was celebrated as such from the end of the 18th century and throughout the 19th century, with Bouilly's play playing a large part in this cult, which was maintained mainly by the Institute for the Deaf and Dumb.
=500  \\$aBouilly is best known for writing a libretto, supposedly based on a true story, about a woman who disguises herself as a man to rescue her husband from prison, which formed the basis of Beethoven's opera Fidelio as well as a number of other operas.
=500  \\$a"Die Brüder, Schauspiel in Fünf Aufzügen" by Friedrich Eberhard Rambach was published in 1798.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.

=500  \\$a"Das Gewissen, ein bürgerliches Trauerspiel in 5 Aufzüge" by August Wilhelm Iffland, 1799.
=500  \\$aLa Bruyère's "L'homme à sentimens, ou Le Tartuffe des mœurs, Comédie en 5 actes et en vers", was first performed at Théâtre Italien, Paris, 1789.  It was based on Sheridan's "The School for Scandal", a comedy of manners in 5 acts, first  performed in London at Drury Lane Theatre 1777.
=500  \\$a" L'homme à trois visages ou Le proscrit,  mélodrame en 3 actes" by Guilbert de Pixérécourt, was first performed in Paris, Théâtre de l'Ambigu, 1801. It was based on "Abällino, der grosse Bandit" by Zschokke (1795).

=245  \\$aDe onechte dochter - Het woud van Hermanstad - Het kind der liefdadigheid, of De nieuwe Antigone - Victorine - De barbaarsche zeerovers, of De man met twee vrouwen
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1806
=300  \\$a80-88-87-114-59 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook

=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak$v14/16
=500  \\$a'De onechte dochter' is an original play by J.Ph. Meijer. The author explains in an introduction he hopes for constructive criticism so that he can decide to further develop the playwright's craft or not.
=500  \\$a'La forêt d'Hermanstad ou La fausse épouse' by Caignur was first published in 1805.
=500  \\$a'La fille de l'hospice, ou La nouvelle Antigone' by Caignur was first published in 1805.

=500  \\$a'Leopold der Schöne, ein Sittengemälde der Vorzeit in fünf Aufzügen' by Josef von Hormayr zu Hortenburg, was first published as patriotic Drama in 1805. Georg Johannes Hammius translated it in Dutch.

=041  \\$aita
=100  \\$aLeti, Gregorio $d1630-1701$4aut$98661
=245  \\$aDialoghi politici o vero La politica che usano in questi tempi, i prencipi, e republiche italiane
=260  \\$aGeneva$bChouët$c1666
=300  \\$a[lxvii]-887 pages$bindex, illustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aGregorio Leti was an Italian historian and satirist from Milan, who sometimes published under the pseudonym Abbe Gualdi, L'abbé Gualdi or Gualdus, known for his works about the Catholic Church, especially the papacy. All of his publications were listed on the Index Librorum Prohibitorum.
=561  \\$aEx Libris Vischi (manuscript)

=008  210527s1689\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\d\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aMolière$d1622-1673$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q687$95673
=245  \\$aLa Princesse d'Élide ensemble les plaisirs de l'isle enchantée
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bLe Jeune$c1689
=300  \\$a108 pages$billustration$c7x13cm
=500  \\$aOne of 10 reprints of Molière's works, collected in a box
=500  \\$aLa Princesse d'Élide is a gallant comedy with music and ballet entries in five acts, first performed at Versailles on 8 May 1664 as part of the sumptuous Plaisirs de l'Île enchantée festival. It was then given to the public at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal on 9 November 1664 by Molière's troupe, then known as the troupe of Monsieur, the King's only brother.
=501  \\$aBound in with 'Dom Garcie de Navarre, ou Le prince jaloux', 'George Dandin ou Le mari confondu', 'L'Escole des femmes', 'L'Escole des maris', 'La Comtesse d'Escarbagnas', 'Le Mariage forcé, 'Le Sicilien ou L'Amour peintre', 'Les Amans magnifiques. Comédie meslée de musique et d'entrées de ballet', and 'Mélicerte. Comédie pastorale héroique'

=651  \0$aFrance$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q142$9131

=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$avla
=100  \\$aRosier, Charles$d1640-1725$4cmp$95681
=245  \\$aQuatorze sonate$bpour les violons et le hautbois à 6 parties
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bRoger$aUtrecht$bTabuteau$c1697 [?]
=300  \\$a16 pages
=500  \\$aLoose haute-contrepart. The five-part instrumentation of the Vingt-quatre Violons (founded in 1626 under Louis XIII ) consisted of the following string instruments: “treble violins,” “contratenor violins,” “tenor violins,” “low-tenor violins” and “bass violins” (dessus, hautes-contres, tailles, quintes de violon & basses de violon)
=500  \\$aThe fourth sonata is known as the 'Kuckuckssonate', as No.4 of QUATORZE SONATE │ Pour les Violons et le Haubois. │ a 6 Parties composés │ par Mr. C. Rosiers,1697 - Amsterdam, see https://imslp.org/wiki/Sonata_in_C_major_'Kuckuckssonate'_(Rosier%2C_Carl)

=LDR  03428 a  a2200337   4500
=001  1025
=008  210607s1762\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\0b\\\\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aPlutarchus$d46-after 119$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q41523$95727
=245  \\$aLes Vies des hommes illustres$cvols. 1-14/14
=260  \\$aParis$bCompagnie des Libraires$c1762
=300  \\$a7 vols. (342+335+379+385+402+349+381 pages)
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aOriginally 'Βίοι Παράλληλοι' (2nd c. AD)
=500  \\$aPlutarch's Lives of the Noble Greeks and Romans, commonly called Parallel Lives or Plutarch's Lives, is a series of 48 biographies of famous men, arranged in pairs to illuminate their common moral virtues or failings, probably written at the beginning of the second century AD.The surviving Parallel Lives (Greek: Βίοι Παράλληλοι, Bíoi Parállēloi) comprises 23 pairs of biographies, each pair consisting of one Greek and one Roman of similar destiny, such as Alexander the Great and Julius Caesar, or Demosthenes and Cicero. 
=500  \\$aAndré Dacier - a first-rate translator, keeper of the King's library and soon to be perpetual secretary of the Académie française - delivered his first six Lives in 1694. He dedicated his entire translation in 1721 to the future Louis XV. Dacier, who first translated for young people, corrected the pagan errors by earlier existing French translations of the Greek tex, and delivered a moralized Plutarch , which reigned in libraries throughout the 18th century.
=504  \\$aindex
=648  \0$aClassical Antiquity (8th Century BC-6th Century AD)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q486761$921435
=650  \0$aBiography$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36279$91927
=650  \0$aBiography$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36279$91927
=700  \\$4aut$4trl$4edt$aDacier, André$d1651-1722$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q518173$95728
=942  \\$cBOO
=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$3vols. 1-2$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_06_05D23$70$8RAR$91025$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$i05D23$l0$oKTS1 C1.06 05D23$p20136551$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO
=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$3vols. 3-4$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_06_05D24$70$8RAR$920238$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$i05D24$l0$oKTS1 C1.06 05D24$p20136662$r2021-06-15 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO
=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$3vols. 5-6$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_06_05D25$70$8RAR$920239$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2021-01-12$eKoopman$i05D25$l0$oKTS1 C1.06 05D25$p20136663$r2021-06-15 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO

Blainville - Examen de deux principes avancés par m. Rameau, dans sa brochure intitulée: Erreurs sur la musique, dans l'Encyclopédie - Lettre à m. Burney, sur la musique, avec fragmens d'observations sur l'Alceste italien de m. le chevalier Gluck - Extrait d'une reponse du petit faiseur a son préte-nom, sur un morceau de l'Orphée de m. le chevalier Gluck.

=041  \\$afre$hspa
=100  \\$aCervantes, Miguel de$d1547-1616$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q5682$95670
=245  \\$aHistoire de l'admirable Don Quichotte de la Manche$nTome troisième
=260  \\$aLyon$bRigollet$c1738
=300  \\$a475-[5] pages$billustrations
=500  \\$a"There are 32 illustrations that refer to Cervantes' Quixote and are copied after Savery's plates (Dordrecht: Savery, 1657 and Brussels: Mommarte, 1662) and Bouttats' plates (Amberes: Verdussen, 1672-73). Twenty refer to Saint Martin's Continuation. The edition is reprinted after Lyon: Th. Amaulry, 1711 (and 1713 for vol. VI), which is also in Lyon: Th. Amaulry, 1718. Cushing's copy has four frontis and 20 illustrations (wanting 3 illus. in vol. I, five illus. in vol. II, four illus. in vol. III, one frontis and eight illus. in vol. IV, five illus. in vol. V and one frontis and seven illus. in vol. VI)." (cervantes.dh.tamu.edu)
=500  \\$aVol. 3/6

=500  \\$aPater Peters - weet zelf niet wat hij vraagt
=500  \\$aTurkschen Keyser - wacht u voor Fransche vossen

=245  \\$aPoetical Greetings from the Far East:$bJapanese Poems
=260  \\$aTokyo$bHasegawa$c1896
=300  \\$a98 pages$b bound with an illustrated colour title on crêpe paper / Hosho paper, illustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aOriginal Japanese Poems of the Manyoshu Collection, the majority dating from the first half of the 8th century. Complete edition, selected, translated from the Japanese by Karl Florenz with a preface and notes. With colored wood engravings of Hanko, Kason, Mishima Yunosuke (Shoso) and Arai Shujiro (Yoshimune).
=500  \\$aPrinted on double leaves of crêpe paper folded in Japanese style.
=500  \\$aEnglish translation by Lloyd of the German Edition of 1894 by Florenz, a pioneer of German Japanology. Lloyd was a minister of the Church of England, fellow and Dean of Peterhouse, Cambridge, academic, translator, and biographer. He also served as an Anglican missionary and academic in Japan from 1884 until his death in 1911.

=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aNepos, Cornelius$dc. 110 BC-c. 25 BC$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q109594$921561
=245  \\$aVitæ excellentium imperatorum
=260  \\$aLeiden$bHack$c1658
=300  \\$a[xxiv]-393-[15] pages
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aCornelius Nepos is the earliest extant Latin biographer. His work 'On Famous Men' grouped and chronicled the lives of about 400 men, both Roman and non-Roman, who he recognized as significant and important men. The only surviving remains of 'On Famous Men' are "On Eminent Foreign Generals" and, from his section on Roman Historians, writings on the lives of Porcius Cato and Atticus.

=500  \\$aCornelis van Alkemade was a Dutch historian and a passionate collector of antiquities, both coins and old manuscripts. Through his many publications, Van Alkemade acquired great authority in his time as a connoisseur of antiquities.
=500  \\$aPieter van der Schelling was a Dutch historian, collector and researcher of antiquities, who, after his marriage in 1717 to Alida van Alkemade began working with his father-in-law Cornelis van Alkemade, also a collector of antiquities. After Cornelis van Alkemade's death in 1737, Pieter van der Schelling continued his work.

=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aThe reverend Burgh had been working as the vicar of St. Lawrence Jewry since 1815. By changing the liturgy in his church, he made himself so unpopular that his parishioners unsuccessfully petitioned Queen Victoria to have him removed. The composer and organist Samuel Wesley was a frequent visitor to Burgh House (Hampstead Village, UK)  at this time; he described Burgh as ‘an odd fellow ... and as diverting as Punch’.

=041  \\$aspa
=100  \\$aIriarte, Tomás de$d1750-1791$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q135326$95814
=245  \\$aLa música.$bPoema
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aMadrid$bImprenta Real$c1784
=300  \\$a[xx]-126-xl pages
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aIriarte (1750-1791) was a neoclassical poet who translated French dramas for the royal theater of Madrid. 'La música', in which he deals with the elements of music, its expression, value, uses in church, the theater and in private life, and possibilities for composition on Spanish texts, forced his international breakthrough.
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1782.

=041  \\$agrc
=100  \\$aAnacreon$d582 BC-485 BC$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q213484$95821
=245  \\$aAnacreontis odaria, ad textus Barnesiani fidem emendata.$bAccedunt variæ lectiones
=250  \\$aEd. altera
=260  \\$aLondon$bHowlett$c1813
=300  \\$a130 pages$billustrations
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aThis edition of Anacreon was originally published in 1802 for which William Bulmer furnished a Greek font; the title-plates and vignettes were by Lavinia Forster.
=500  \\$aAnacreon (582 BC-485 BC) was a Greek lyric poet, notable for his drinking songs and erotic poems.  Anacreon wrote all of his poetry in the ancient Ionic dialect. Like all early lyric poetry, it was composed to be sung or recited to the accompaniment of music, usually the lyre. Anacreon's poetry touched on universal themes of love, infatuation, disappointment, revelry, parties, festivals and the observations of everyday people and life.
=500  \\$aEdition based on the one of Joshua Barnes (1705) 
=500  \\$a3 poems are translated in english, pensil, manuscript
=590  \\$acura Edvardi Forster
=648  \0$aClassical Antiquity (8th Century BC-6th Century AD)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q486761$921435

=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aBingham, Joseph$d1668-1723$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q636694$95831
=245  \\$aOrigines sive Antiquitates ecclesiasticæ 
=260  \\$aHalle$bOrphanotrophei$c1724, 1727, 1729
=300  \\$a10 vols. (48-360 + 28-447 + 20-619-[38] + 20-411 + 12-348 + 16-592 + 14-522 +12-288 + 20-364 + 64-100-[344] pages)
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aBingham (1668-1723) was an ecclesiastical historian
=500  \\$athe ten vols. of "Origines ecclesiasticæ" originally appeared between 1708 and 1722
=500  \\$aHis design, learnedly, exhaustively and impartially executed, was to give such a methodical account of the antiquities of the Christian Church as others have done of the Greek and Roman and Jewish antiquities, by reducing the ancient customs, usages and practices of the church under certain proper heads, whereby the reader may take a view at once of any particular usage or custom of Christians for four or five centuries.
=504  \\$aindex
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aReligion$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q9174$93062
=650  \0$aHistory$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q309$921403
=856  \\$uhttps://books.google.be/books?id=Mms6MQAACAAJ; https://books.google.be/books?id=2acPAAAAQAAJ; https://books.google.be/books?id=nAhlAAAAcAAJ$3Google Books

=505  \\$gWeet ge, moeder, wat ik droomde? (Weisst Du Muatterl, was i träumt hab’?): Lied. Voor zang en piano / Alois Kutschera -- Air Favori du Prince Louis de Rohan: Gavotte du Cardinal pour piano-solo / Henry Kooy -- Cavalleria Rusticana: Intermezzo sinfonico voor piano forte (tweehandig) / Pietro Mascagni -- Impatience Rondo-Galop transcription pour piano op.98 (L. =008  220714b\\\\\\\\|||||l||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre$dlat
=059  \\$avv org
=100  \\$aLanglais, Jean$d1907-1991$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q551533$95835
=245  \\$aMesse solennelle:$b4 voix mixtes et orgue
=260  \\$aParis$bSchola Cantorum
=300  \\$a32 pages
=500  \\$aJean François-Hyacinthe Langlais III (1907-1991) was a French composer of modern classical music, organist, and improviser. He described himself as "Breton, de foi Catholique" ("Breton, of Catholic faith"). His works include masses and organ music, some based on Gregorian themes, enhanced by polymodal harmonies, as well as secular music. Langlais became blind due to glaucoma when he was only two years old and was sent to the Institut National des Jeunes Aveugles (National Institute for Blind Children) in Paris, where he began to study the organ with André Marchal. From there he progressed to the Paris Conservatoire, obtaining prizes in organ and studying composition with Marcel Dupré and Paul Dukas.
=500  \\$awith autograph of the composer on title page
=561  \\$aEx libris Joseph Hetsch (stamp)

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGrétry, André-Ernest-Modeste$d1741-1813$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q210962$94756
=245  \\$aLucile.$bComédie en un acte et en vers
=260  \\$aParis$bGrétry$c1769 [?]
=300  \\$a131 pages
=500  \\$athe characters in the opera, though not the actual story, were derived from "L'école des pères", one of Marmontel's Contes moraux ("Moral Tales"). The melody from "Où peut-on être mieux qu'au sein de sa famille?" was later reused in Vieuxtemps' Violin Concerto No. 5, Op.37
=500  \\$a05J08: short ms. notes in ink about the opera on front matter
=500  \\$a05J08: contains the stamp of the publisher Jenny Grétry
=500  \\$a Ex libris Alessandro Kraus Figlio, Via dei Cerretani N. 10, Firenze (stamp; compare with 01A06 and 09L24). Alessandro Kraus jr. (1853-1931) was a musicologist, pianist and collector of exotic—particularly Japanese—instruments (which helped inspire Pietro Mascagni's 'Iris'). 
=520  \\$aLucile is enjoying a morning preparing for her wedding. She is joined by her fiancé young Dorval, her father Timante and Dorval's father. The celebrations are interrupted by the old peasant Blaise, who reveals that his wife has just confided a secret to him on her deathbed: she had been a wet nurse to Timante's child, but when the baby died she decided to hide the truth and exchange it for her own daughter to ensure a better future for the latter. The grown-up child is Lucile. Lucile's poor background means she can no longer marry the middle-class Dorval. However, Timante persuades Dorval's father to let the wedding go ahead regardless and the opera concludes with general rejoicing.
=534  \\$aPremiered at the Comédie-italienne, Paris, 5 January 1769
=561  \\$a01A22: Ex libris Alessandro Kraus Figlio (Stamp)
=590  \\$adédiée a son excellence Monsiegneur, le comte D'Oultremont frere et premier ministre de son altesse moneigneur le prince-Evêque de Liège

=500  \\$aThe opera was the first to have excerpts sung in the air - thanks to Élisabeth Thible, the first woman aeronaut, who, dressed as Minerva, sung impromptu arias from the opera to an audience below her including Gustav III, from a Montgolfier balloon in 1784.

=520  \\$a'Orpheus Britannicus' is a collection of songs by Henry Purcell, published posthumously in London in two volumes, the first in 1698 and the second in 1702. 
=534  \\$aVol. 1 was originally published in 1698
=561  \\$aEx librs S. H. Sutherland (manuscript)
=561  \\$aEx libris James Th. Law, Lichfield 1850 (manuscript)
James Thomas Law (1790–1876) was an English cleric, the chancellor of the diocese of Lichfield from 1821. 
=561  \\$aEx libris R. R. Henshaw(?),  Bath, 1944

=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$avn
=245  \\$a9me Année Violino - 10me Année Violino
=260  \\$as.l.$bs.n.$c17xx
=300  \\$a[40] pages
=500  \\$aConvolute of violin parts, published as 'L'année violino' vol. 9, nos. 1-12 and vol. 10, nos. 1-4
=500  \\$aIn vol.9, Nr.8 is missing, and between Nr.7 and Nr.9 four pages have been inserted from another print of violin parts with ouvertures by Jean Baptiste Lemoyne for 'Pommiers et du Moulin' (1789)  and 'Louis IX en Egypte' (1790)
=500  \\$aContains amongst others Ouvertures for L'Impresario in angustie (Cimarosa),  La pastorella nobile (Guglielmi), Le vicende amore (Guglielmi), La molinarella (Piccini), Le gelosie villane (Sarti), L'Italiana in Londra (Cimarosa), Raoul de Créqui (Cimarosa), Il fanatico burlaco (Cimarosa), La bella pescatrice (Guglielmi), Euphrosine (Méhul), La soirée orageuse (Dalayrac), Il burbero di buon core (Martin y Soler), La ballerina amante (Cimarosa) and Il convito (Cimarosa). Contains also ballets and opera-airs from  amongst others 'Le Tuteur Avare' (Jean-Louis Gabiot) as well as from unidentified opera's 'Démophon', 'Télémaque', 'Oedipe', 'Didon' and 'Danaides'. 
=500  \\$aa label on the cover shows the table of contents of the collection
=501  \\$aBound in with Trois Sonates op.4, Trois Sonates op.6, Deux Sonates op.10, Trois Sonates op.5, Trois Sonates op.1, Trois Sonates op.3, Deux Sonates op.3, Six Sonates op.18, and Six Sonates op.17=30

=001  1203
=005  20250926135308.0
=008  220628s1779\\\\|||||a||\||||\00|\0\ger\d
=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$aSATB 2ob 2tpt tpt2 timp 2vn vla bc
=100  \\$aBach, Carl Philipp Emanuel$d1714-1788$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q76428$99218
=240  \\$aWq. 217
=245  \\$aHeilig, mit zwei Chören und einer Ariette zur Einleitung
=260  \\$aHamburg$bBach$aLeipzig$bBreitkopf$c1779
=300  \\$a22 pages
=500  \\$aContains list of subscribers
=500  \\$aPerformed by the Nederlands Kamerkoor and Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra conducted by Ton Koopman at the 1988 Oude Muziek Festival of Utrecht.
=520  \\$aIn a letter to Breitkopf from 1776, C. P. E. Bach noted about his "Heilig": "Hier habe ich den meisten und kühnsten Fleiß bewiesen zu einer guten Ausnahme. Dieses Heilig ist ein Versuch, durch ganz natürliche harmonische Fortschreibungen weit stärkere Aufmerksamkeit und Empfindung zu erregen, als man mit aller ängstlicher Chromatik nicht im Stande ist zu thun. Es soll mein Schwanenlied von dieser Art sein, und dazu dienen, daß man meiner nach meinem Tod nicht zu bald vergessen möge."
=534  \\$aPremiered at the St. Michaeliskirche of Hamburg, 27 September 1776

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aMoreau, Pierre$dc. 1599-1648$4aut$4egr$4bkd$4ill$95917
=245  \\$aDévotes prières$bEscrites et burinées apres le naturel de la Plume
=260  \\$aParis$bHenault$c1648
=300  \\$a[iv]-168 pages$bengraved title page, portrait of Louis XIII, caligraphic fonts, vignets illustrations and embellishments throughout, 15 full page engravings$c5x8 cm
=500  \\$aPierre Moreau was a French master writer, caligrapher, engraver and printer.
=500  \\$aExtraordinary fine palm-sized caligraphic book of prayers, dedicated by the printer Jean Henault (16..-1673) to the French King Louis XIII
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1634
=500  \\$aPierre Moreau appears in typographic history as a meteor: brilliant, even dazzling, but ephemeral. Coming from calligraphy, he only came to typography at the end of his career. In 1643, probably protected, Moreau became the king's printer; between 1643 and his death in 1648 he published about thirty works with his typefaces, mainly devotional texts and poetic or dramatic texts. Their typographic particularity and the sharpness of their printing make them still sought after today. 
=500  \\$aNote of Ton Koopman : "Prachtig boekje in marocijn" "einde verkeerd gebonden m[aar] compleet"
=500  \\$aloose leaflet with manuscript note "...chaque page est entournée de vignette et toutes sont différentes. Le tout gravé et non pas emprimé"
=504  \\$aIsabelle de Conihout et Frédéric Gabriel (dir.), Poésie & calligraphie imprimée à Paris au XVIIe siècle : autour de La Chartreuse de Pierre Perrin, poème imprimé par Pierre Moreau en 1647, Paris et Chambéry, 2004 [contains a comprehensive bibliography of his engraved collections and printed editions].

=LDR  04616 a  a2200457   4500
=001  1265
=008  211221s1735\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\p\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGresset, Jean-Baptiste$d1709-1777$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q942163$95926
=245  \\$aVer-Vert ou Les voyages du perroquet de Nevers. $bPoème héroique
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bs.n.$c1735
=300  \\$a[iv]-32 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1734
=500  \\$aheroic-comic poem in four songs about a parrot
=500  \\$aAlthough domestication has existed for a very long time, the attachment of humans to animals, a feeling that seems natural to us today, has not always existed. It is estimated that it was in the 18th century that a deep attachment to animals emerged among the elites. At that time, the figure of the animal became an important subject of study and a fashionable theme, as illustrated by the poem Vert-vert, written in 1734 by the Jesuit Jean-Baptiste-Louis Gresset. This story, whose eponymous hero is a parrot, is indicative of the interest in domestic animals in the 18th century.
=500  \\$aThe story is pleasant, and Vert-vert was a considerable success, as numerous 18th and 19th century editions prove. However, the poem did not please the sisters of the Visitation, who had Gresset sanctioned. Relegated to the college of La Flèche, he finally left the orders in 1735. He continued to write, however, and became an academician in 1748.
=501  \\$aLa Pupille / Règlement pour l'Opéra de Paris / Le Caresme In-promptu et Le lutrin vivant. 
=504  \\$ahttps://bibulyon.hypotheses.org/1539
=520  \\$athe Visitandines of Nevers take in a parrot they name Vert-Vert. They give him all their attention and teach him some pious songs. Proud of their parrot, they decided to send it to the Visitation in Nantes. But on the journey, Vert-vert learns the coarse language of the boatmen and, when he arrives at the convent in Nantes, he scandalizes the nuns who immediately send him away. Back in Nevers, Vert-vert is so pampered that he dies of indigestion.
=520  \\$aUnderneath its light-hearted appearance, Vert-vert reflects a reality, the possession of pets in convents, and certain preoccupations of the Enlightenment. Thus Gresset chose a parrot as the main character at a time when these birds were the object of a real craze in France. Sources of prestige for their masters, parrots also interest scholars because, through their ability to speak, they blur the line between man and animal. This new interest led to lively debates on the existence of suffering in animals: while some admitted it, others restricted it to physical pain. Others still consider it non-existent, such as the Cartesians, who believe that God can make an animal suffer, an innocent creature untouched by original sin, is to think that God is unjust.

Finally, while Jean-Baptiste-Louis Gresset tells this story with humour, others use it to criticise an excessive attachment to animals, an attachment that is all the more dangerous because it is likely to divert man from his duties towards his fellow human beings and towards God. This is the case of La Critique de Vairvert, an anonymous satirical play published in 1748.
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=100  \\$aHoratius$d65 BC-8 BC$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6197$94875
=245  \\$aTraduction des odes d'Horace,$bavec des observations critiques et poésies lyriques$n1-2/2
=260  \\$aParis$bValade$c1781
=300  \\$a2 vols. (xxiv-354-[2] + xii-312 pages)
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aThe Odes (Latin: Carmina) are a collection in four books of Latin lyric poems by Horace. The Horatian ode format and style has been emulated since by other poets.  Books 1 to 3 were published in 23 BC. A fourth book, consisting of 15 poems, was published in 13 BC.
=504  \\$ahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odes_(Horace)

=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$aorg hpd lute bc
=100  \\$aMasson, Charles$dfl. 1680-1700$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q57634854$95944
=245  \\$aNouveau traité des règles pour la composition de la musique
=250  \\$a4th ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bBallard$c1738
=300  \\$a[viii]-128 pages
=500  \\$aRISM B-VI, p. 555
=500  \\$aMasson was a French Church musician. Around 1680, he was director of music at the cathedral of Châlon-sur-Marne, then at the professed house of the Jesuits in Paris. He was one of the first to present only the major and minor modes, and to use the bass to construct the counterpoint.
=501  \\$aBound in with 'Élémens de Musique, théorique et pratique suivant les principes de M. Rameau'
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1708
=561  \\$aex libris Henri Prunières (plate)
=590  \\$aPar lequel on apprend à faire facilement un chant sur des paroles à composer à 2. à 3. & à 4. parties, &c. Et à chiffrer la Basse-Continuë, suivant l'usage des meilleurs auteurs. Ouvrage très-utile à ceux qui joüent de l'orgue, du clavecin, & du théorbe. Par C. Masson, cy-devant Maître de Musique de la Cathédrale de Châlons, en Champagne, & de S. Loüis de la Maison Professe des RR. P. Jésuites
=610  \0$aJesuits$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36380$921140

=260  \\$aDelft$bBoitet$c1732
=300  \\$a393-[3] pages$bbound in white vellum
=500  \\$aSynods of the Dutch Reformed Church were councils convened to decide on issues of doctrine, bible translations, administration or application, to establish rules, putting an end to religious controversy etc. This book contains the acts of the Synods of Dordrecht (1618-19), The Hague (1586), Middelburg (1581), Dordrecht (1574) and Emden (1571), alongside various resolutions from synods held between 1651-1730

=041  \\$ager$afre$aita
=100  \\$aCocceji, Heinrich von$d1644-1719$4ctb$921582
=245  \\$aAlbum amicorum A. L. Prisomann von Nettig
=260  \\$aFrankfurt an der Oder$c1699
=300  \\$a106 pages
=500  \\$aRemarkable friendship album of the Ödenburg (today Sopron, HU) councillor and patrician Ägidius Prisomann.
=500  \\$aThe volume does not contain any mottoes, but rather extensive ballads, songs and vaudevilles, mainly in German, but also in French and Italian. Many entries are not signed by name or are only monogrammed, only a few are dated. Among the well-known co-bearers are several renowned jurists and scholars, among them Heinrich von Cocceji and his sons Johann Gottfied and Samuel.
=504  \\$aIncludes an index
=533  \\$aDigitized by iGuana, Spring 2022
=561  \\$a"Aus der Bibliothek von Moriz Boehm FUERTH." (stamp); shelfmark or catalog number 1233 (ms., pencil)
=563  \\$aContemporary leather binding with gilded supralibros on the front cover: AE(gidius) L(udwig) P(risomann) V(on) N(ettig)
=590  \\$aBestehend in allerhand schönen Airen, so von guten Freunden zum steten ehrenden Angedenken sind eingeschrieben worden

=059  \\$avn
=100  \\$aExaudet, André-Joseph$dc. 1710-1762$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q516384$95993
=245  \\$a[Petit cahier manuscrit à l'usage d'un violoniste]
=260  \\$as.l.$cc. 1800
=300  \\$a29 pages$c16x9 cm$boblong
=500  \\$aMelodic parts of songs and dances; 42 numbered pieces in one hand, 3 pieces marked "1824" in another hand (Allemande vivace, Il Pescator, Valse moderato). Probably intended for use by a dancing master, judging from the contents and dimensions. Contains various dance forms: valses, contredanses, menuets, allemandes, cotillon, rondes paysannes, and tambourin
=500  \\$aSeparate leaflet with notes from a former owner: "Main A: 42 pieces [Exaudet (11), Grétry (16,34), Martini (41), Monsigny (19), etc...] | Main B: 3 pièces ajoutées en 1824"
=500  \\$aNo. 11, the 'Menuet d'Exaudet' was a popular couple-dance of which there remains a choreographic notation by Claude-Marc Magny in his 'Principes de chorégraphie' (Paris, 1765); no. 16, the 'Marche de Huron', originates from Grétry's opéra-comique 'Le Huron' (1768); no. 34, 'Andante Nos cœurs', originates from Grétry's opéra-comique 'Silvain' (1770); no. 19 is the overture of Monsigny's opéra-comique 'Le Déserteur' (1769)
=533  \\$aDigitized by iGuana, Spring 2022

=041  \\$adut$hlat
=100  \\$aBourgoingne, Anton van$d1594-1657$4aut$95994
=245  \\$aGhebreken der tonghe ende middelen om die te verbeteren
=260  \\$aAntwerp$bCnobbaert$c1631
=300  \\$a[xvi]-381 pages$boblong, bound in white vellum, illustrations, engraved frontispiece
=500  \\$aNeolatine poetry, emblema, influence of Desiderius Erasmus
=500  \\$aOriginally published in  latin as 'Linguae vitia et remedia (Antwerp, Joannes Cnobbaert, 1631). A modern edition of the Latin text, by Toon Van Houdt, was published by Brepols in 1999.
=500  \\$aAnton vann Bourgoigne  born in Bruges to an illegitimate line of descent from the medieval dukes of Burgundy, was a prelate and author of emblem books in the 17th-century Low Countries
=500  \\$aThe work isstrongly inspired by 'Lingua 'by Erasmus. Early on in the Middle Ages, the deadly sins split off into 'the sins of the tongue'. The emblem volume has 94 engravings by Jacobus Neefs (1610-1665) and Andreas Pauli (1600-1639). Each print contains a verse about 'quade tonghen'. The series of forty-five sins are followed by 'means to remedy the defects'
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923

=041  \\$ager
=245  \\$aMusen Almanach für 1787
=260  \\$aHamburg$bBohn$c1787
=300  \\$a[xxxiii]-233-[7] pages$bengraved title page, music examples
=500  \\$aModeled after the French 'Almanach des Muses' (see 09A29, 11A07 and 1B19), the 'Musen-Almanach' was founded in Göttingen in 1770 (see H1-019-20). Johann Heinrich Voß (1751-1826) became its editor in 1774, but in 1775 founded his own almanac in Hamburg.
=500  \\$aAnother competing almanac was founded by Schiller (see H3-011 & X1B18)

=500  \\$aA Walloon church is a Calvinist church in the Netherlands and its former colonies, whose members originate from the Southern Netherlands and France and whose language is French. A synod is a council of a Christian denomination, usually convened to decide an issue of doctrine, administration or application.

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aDonneau de Visé, Jean$d1638-1710$4edt$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3171779$96016
=245  \\$aLe Nouveau Mercure galant$pOctober-December 1678
=260  \\$aParis$c1678
=300  \\$a3 vols in 1 ([iv]-209-[6]-[iv]-193-[3]-[xii]-167-[3] pages)$bcontains engraved illustrations and several fold-out songs with printed music
=500  \\$amultiple songs with printed music in fold-outs, some with one, some with two voices or with voice and basso continuo.
=505  \\$gOctobre 1678 contains for instance a fold-out schematic map of the bridge of Strassbourg, an article with many engravings on medals and at the end two full page engravings with a man and a woman in 'Habit d'Hyver 1678'.
Novembre 1678 contains another description of a medal and a 'Plan de la ville et du chateau de Liechtemberg', a 'Table Genealogique de la Maison des Ducs Sforze'.
Decembre 1678 contains a wonderful depiction and description of the 'Laboratoire des Capucins du Louvre' the royal apothecary. And many other topics.

=041  \\$afre$hlat
=100  \\$aCalvin, Jean$d1509-1564$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q37577$95913
=245  \\$aLes Pseaumes de David, mis en rime françoise
=260  \\$aParis$bCellier$c1662
=300  \\$a[204] pages$bmusic examples
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1551, the translations of 150 Psalms of David by Clement Marot (1496-1544) as completed by Theodore de Bèze (1519-1605, Calvin's successor as spiritual leader of the Republic of Geneva) were used almost exclusively by the Calvinists (Genevan Psalter). The psalter was the main medium of popular fervour among the Reformed. 
=563  \\$aBeautiful leather binding with gilded ornaments on the cover
=648  \0$a16th Century (1501-1600)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7017$920944
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923
=650  \0$aProtestantism$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q23540$921012
=650  \0$aPsalm$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12497663$92164
=650  \0$aSong$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7366$94164
=651  \0$aFrance$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q142$9131
=653  \\$ageen fermates, wel punten$3wb$932073$020139916$w06O09
=700  \\$aMarot, Clément$d1496-1544$4trl$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q108926$95914
=700  \\$aBèze, Théodore de$d1519-1605$4trl$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q314981$96017

=008  211223s1789\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\ideng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aWortley Montagu, Mary$d1689-1762$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q235121$96026
=245  \\$aLetters of the Right Honourable Lady M--y W--y M--e:$bWritten during her Travels in Europe, Asia, and Africa$n1-2/2
=260  \\$aLondon$bCadell$c1789
=300  \\$a2 vols. (xi-[ii]-220 + 272 pages)$bengraved frontispiece
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aLady Mary Wortley Montagu (née Pierrepont, 1689-1762) was an English aristocrat, writer, and poet. She is chiefly remembered for her letters, particularly her Turkish Embassy Letters describing her travels to the Ottoman Empire, as wife to the British ambassador to Turkey, which Billie Melman described as "the very first example of a secular work by a woman about the Muslim Orient". Her writings address and challenge the hindering contemporary social attitudes towards women and their intellectual and social growth. She had  a very special life-story and was often portrayed, as evidenced by the many paintings there are of her.
=500  \\$afrontispiece portrait of the Author in vol.1
=500  \\$aEdition 1763 in 3 vols. Digitalisation vol.1: https://books.google.be/books?id=YkMVAAAAQAAJ
=504  \\$a Melman, Billie. Women's Orients: English Women and the Middle East, 1718–1918. University of Michigan Press. 1992. Print.
=590  \\$aTo persons of distinction, Men of Letters, &c. in different Parts of Europe. Which contain among others accounts of the policy and manners of the Turks; Drawn from sources that have been inaccessible to other travelers? An new editidion to which are added Poems by the same author.

=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 140-146
=500  \\$aEx Libris Genreral Hospital Birminham: Birmingham's civic and choral tradition produced together the Birmingham Festival which originated in the 1750s and 1760s under the auspices of Saint Martin Church and the General Hospital. Handel's Oratorios provided the musical fulcrum until Mendelssohn displaced him in the 1830ies.

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aHercules, an Oratorio in Score. Composed in the Year 1744 [HWV 60]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1787-97
=300  \\$a248 pages$bFrontispiece engraving of the composer
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 34-39
=500  \\$aLibrettist Broughton, a lover of music, knew Handel, and supplied words for some of his compositions, including a libretto based on Sophocles' Women of Trachis and the ninth book of Ovid's Metamophises for the drama Hercules, first performed at the Haymarket in 1745.Handel's biographer, Paul Henry Lang, praises Broughton's libretto for its "good theatrical sense" and the way in which it peels away any extraneous elements of the narrative to concentrate on the central drama of jealousy.

=041  \\$alat

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aA Grand Te Deum for the Peace of Utrech. Composed in the Year 1713 [HWV 278]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1788
=300  \\$a48 pages
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 15-16
=500  \\$aTo celebrate the Treaty of Utrecht, which established the Peace of Utrecht in 1713, ending the War of the Spanish Succession, Händel composed a Te Deum, HWV 278, and a Jubilate Deo (Psalm 100), HWV 279. The combination of the two texts in English follows earlier models. The official premiere of the work was on 13 July 1713 in a service in St Paul's Cathedral in London. 
=501  \\$aA Grand Jubilate [HWV 279]
=585  \\$aThis exemplar was exhibited in 2013 at 'In vredesnaam: De Vrede van Utrecht, Rastatt en Baden, 1713-1714' (Centraal Museum, Utrecht; Wehrgeschichtliches Museum, Rastatt; Historisches Museum, Baden), see de Bruin & Brinkman 2013
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=240  \\$aSolomon, HWV 67
=245  \\$aSolomon, $ba Sacred Oratorio In Score
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1790
=300  \\$a344 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 85-92
=500  \\$aMinor annotations in pencil (crosses, corrections in the accidentals, and additions in the figured bass) at pages 51-53, 77, 89, 90, 96, 119, 133, 244, 265, 267, 268, 309, and 315; in ink at pages 71, 248, 283, 285, and 288
=520  \\$a'Solomon' is based on the biblical stories of the wise king Solomon from the First Book of Kings and the Second Book of Chronicles, with additional material from Antiquities of the Jews by ancient historian Flavius Josephus. The music was composed between 5 May and 13 June 1748, and the first performance took place on 17 March 1749, with Caterina Galli in the title role at the Covent Garden Theatre in London, where it had two further performances. Handel revived the work in 1759.
=561  \\$aEx Libris William Pole Birmingham (plate and manuscript on title page)
=563  \\$aLeather binding with marbled-paper front and back, heavily restored
=590  \\$aWith all the additional Alterations, Composed in the Year 1749

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=240  \\$aLet Thy Hand Be Strengthened, HWV 259; Zadock the Priest, KWV 258; My Heart is Inditing, HWV 261
=245  \\$a3 Anthems, for the Coronation of George IId. Composed in the year 1727 
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$cc. 1785
=300  \\$a18-28-44 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 157-159
=500  \\$aOn 11 October 1727 George II and his wife Caroline of Ansbach were crowned King and Queen of Great Britain and Ireland. The ceremony at Westminster Abbey was preceded by a magnificent procession. Handel was commissioned to write four coronation anthems. He uses text from the King James Bible. They are Zadok the Priest, Let Thy Hand Be Strengthened, The King Shall Rejoice (missing in this collection), and My Heart Is Inditing. Each was originally a separate work but they were later published together.
=501  \\$aAnthem, for the Wedding of Frederick Prince of Wales, and the Princess of Saxa-Gotha. Composed in the Year 1736
Anthem, for the Funeral of Queen Caroline. Composed in the Year 1737
Anthem, for the Victory at Dettingen. Composed in the Year 1743

=240  \\$aThe King Shall Rejoice, HWV 265
=245  \\$aAnthem, for the Victory at Dettingen.$bComposed in the Year 1743
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$cc. 1795
=300  \\$a44 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 156-157
=501  \\$aBound in with 'Anthem, for the Wedding of Frederick Prince of Wales, and the Princess of Saxa-Gotha. Composed in the Year 1736', 'Anthem, for the Funeral of Queen Caroline. Composed in the Year 1737' and 
'3 Anthems, for the Coronation of George IId. Composed in the year 1727'
=520  \\$aThe Battle of Dettingen took place on 27 June 1743 during the War of the Austrian Succession at Dettingen in the Electorate of Mainz, Holy Roman Empire (now Karlstein am Main in Bavaria). It was fought between a Pragmatic Army, composed of the British, Hanoverian and Austrian troops, and a French army commanded by the duc de Noailles. While the Earl of Stair exercised operational control, the Allied army was nominally commanded by George II, accompanied by his son the Duke of Cumberland. As a result, it is now best remembered as the last time a reigning British monarch led troops in combat.
Despite being an Allied victory, the battle had little effect on the wider war, and has been described as 'a happy escape, rather than a great victory.'
=600  \0$aGeorge II$cKing of Great Britain$d1683-1760$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q131981$925011
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=041  \\$aeng
=059  \\$aS A T B SATB 2ob 2tpt timp 2vn vla bc
=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=240  \\$aSing Unto God, Ye Kingdoms of the Earth, HWV 263
=245  \\$aAnthem, for the Wedding of Frederick Prince of Wales, and the Princess of Saxa-Gotha. Composed in the Year 1736.
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$cs.d.
=300  \\$a87 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 153-154
=501  \\$aBound in with 'Anthem, for the Funeral of Queen Caroline. Composed in the Year 1737', 'Anthem, for the Victory at Dettingen. Composed in the Year 1743' and '3 Anthems, for the Coronation of George IId. Composed in the year 1727' 
=520  \\$aFrederick, Prince of Wales (1707-1751)  son and heir of King George II, married Princess Augusta of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg (1719-1772) in 1736. He was the eldest son of George II and Queen Caroline and father to the future George III. He spent much of his life at odds with his own father. He was excluded from both the business of ruling and the public eye and thus used art and music to establish himself amongst the aristocracy and court. Today he is remembered as a great lover and patron of music. Frederick spent his early years in Germany and during his education there he became proficient at both the cello and the harpsichord. In 1733 Frederick formed his own opera company called the Opera of the Nobility. Its first principal composer was Nicola Porpora, later the teacher of Haydn. This was a bold move at the time as it was set up to rival the Royal Academy of Music, which was established by Handel and officially patronised by his father, George II. This is not to say, however, that Frederick was antagonistic towards Handel. 
=600  \0$aFrederick$cPrince of Wales$d1707-1751$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q165349$926923
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aAnthem$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q541947$92161
=650  \0$aWedding$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q49836$922203
=651  \0$aUnited Kingdom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q21$9273

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aAn Ode or Serenata for the Birth Day of Queen Ann Composed in the Year 1736$b['Eternal Source of Light Divine', HWV 74]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1789 [?]
=300  \\$a44 pages
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 54
=500  \\$aAnne, Princess Royal and Princess of Orange (1709-1759)[ was the second child and eldest daughter of King George II of Great Britain and his consort Caroline of Ansbach. She was the wife of William IV, Prince of Orange, the first hereditary stadtholder of all seven provinces of the Northern Netherlands. She was taught music (including singing, harpsichord, and composition) by Georg Friedrich Händel. Händel did not like teaching, but said he would "make the only exception for Anne, flower of princesses". She remained a lifelong supporter, attending his operas and subscribing to his music.

=245  \\$aOde on St. Cecilia's Day, the Words by Dryden: Set to Musick in the Year 1736$b['From Harmony", HWV 76]
=246  \1$aFrom Harmony, from Heav'nly Harmony, HWV 76
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$cc. 1792
=300  \\$a74 pages
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 105-6
=500  \\$aDate of composition is wrong, not 1736 but 1739.
=500  \\$aHandel sets a poem which the English poet John Dryden wrote in 1687. The main theme of the text is the Pythagorean theory of harmonia mundi, that music was a central force in the Earth's creation. 
=501  \\$aAn Ode or Serenata for the Birth Day of Queen Ann. Composed in the Year 1736

=245  \\$aJoshua, a Sacred Oratorio in Score. Composed in the Year 1747 $b[HWV 64]
=260  \\$aLondon$c1789$bArnold
=300  \\$a169-[1] pages
=336  \\$anotated music
=336  \\$aprinted
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 56-60
=500  \\$aJoshua is based on the Biblical story of Joshua as the leader of the ancient Israelites. The story follows the Israelites from their passage over the Jordan River into Caanan and through the Battle of Jericho. The work also includes a love story elaborated from a few hints in the Biblical narrative between Caleb's daughter Achsah and Othniel, a young soldier.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aTrydell, John$4aut$96040
=245  \\$aMusick: Excerpt from the 1st Edition of the Encyclopædia Britannica
=250  \\$a1st
=260  \\$aEdinburgh$bBell$bMacfarquhar$c1771c
=300  \\$a[38] pages$b9 folded pages of music examples
=336  \\$abook
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aJohn Trydell (also Triddel / Tridel, c. 1715-1776) was an Irish theorist who in 1766 authored 'Two Essays on the Theory and Practice of Music', see 10C19 and H2-039
=500  \\$aTrydell was also ordained deacon and installed rector of Kilnamanagh
=500  \\$avery elaborate article with music examples
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=008  220321s1819\\\\|||||l||\||||\00|\0\ger\d
=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$akbd
=100  \\$aSchicht, Johann Gottfried$d1753-1823$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q289660$96041
=245  \\$aAllgemeines Choral-Buch für Kirchen, Schulen, Gesangvereine, Orgel- und Pianoforte- Spieler:$bVierstimmig gesetzt$nvols. 1-3
=260  \\$aLeipzig$bBreitkopf & Härtel$c1819
=300  \\$a10-547 pages$coblong
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$a3 vols. in 1
=500  \\$ams. note in front matter: "Mon très cher ami, F. Martini, dèja attaché au lit par sa maladie, m'a fait present de cette oeuvre la veille de noël 1842 Rr. (?)"
=500  \\$aJohann Gottfried Schicht (1753-1823) was a German composer and conductor. He was the conductor of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra from 1785 to 1810, when he was succeeded by Johann Philipp Christian Schulz. Schicht continued to work in Leipzig, serving as Thomaskantor, director of the Thomanerchor with responsibility for music in the city's churches. He was in post from 1810 until 1823, when he died, aged 69, in Leipzig.
=500  \\$aHis most important work is this great choirbook from 1819. Besides that, he wrote masses, motets, cantatas, a setting of the 100th Psalm, four Te deums, one piano concerto, sonatas and capriccio. He is believed to have been the editor of the first edition of Bach's motets.
=648  \0$a19th Century (1801-1900)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6955$920935
=650  \0$aChorale$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q724473$921334
=650  \0$aOrgan music$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2003283$91951
=650  \0$aPiano$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q5994$92127
=651  \0$aLeipzig (Germany)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2079$945
=856  \\$uhttps://reader.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/fs1/object/display/bsb10525226_00001.html$3vol. 1

=856  \\$uhttps://reader.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/fs1/object/display/bsb10525228_00001.html$3vol. 3

=100  \\$aFenaroli, Fedele$d1730-1818$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3740837$96147
=245  \\$aRegole musicali per li principianti di cembalo
=250  \\$aNuova edizione accresciuta
=260  \\$as.l.$cafter 1795
=300  \\$a64 pages
=500  \\$aManuscript copy of a publication; erroneously ascribed in manuscript (ink) in the inner cover to "Giuseppe Fuxe autore celebre di Musica"
=500  \\$aCorpus of 54 pages, containing Fenaroli's 'Delle cadenze, delle dissonanze, delle legature, de movimenti del partimento', with an annex of 8 pages containing 'Alcuni Ricordi fondamentali di musica', i.e., personal remarks with musical examples, probably by Luigi Bochioli.
