=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aDanser Nyman, Jan$d?-c. 1798$4col$96079
=245  \\$aCatalogus van een Ongemeene Capitaale Collectie Prent-Kunst
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bCrajenschot$bIJver$c[1798]
=300  \\$a378 pages (182 printed pages, 196 pages of interleaves)
=500  \\$aContains numerous annotations on interleaves indicating the buyers (among other Reinier Vinkeles) and the prices the artworks fetched at auction, on 19 March 1798
=533  \\$aDigitized by iGuana, Spring 2022
=590  \\$aWaar in Uitmunten de Heerlyke Werken; naar P. P. Rubbens [sic], Antony van Dyck, J. Jordaans; verders eigen geëtste door Rembrant, A. van Ostade, N. Berchem, en andere; keurlyke zwarte Kunst-Prenten, extra fraaije Geponsonneerde, en in de manier als Teekeningen, en andere Gegraveerde; door de Beroemdste Engelsche, Fransche en Nederlandsche Kunst-Graveerders; waar onder een meenigte Proefdrukken, en zeldzaam voorkoomende, alle zindelyk Geconditioneert. Capitaale gebonden, en losse prent-werken, Beneevens twee keurlyke Kunst-Kasten. Naargelaaten door wylen den Heere Jan Danser Nyman, Al het welke naar het Kabinet Teekeningen; ter zelver plaats, door gemelde Makelaars zal Verkogt worden.

=500  \\$aFeijoo was a Benedictine Monk, scholar, essayist and literary critic, who led the Age of Enlightenment in Spain. He was an energetic popularizer noted for encouraging scientific and empirical thought in an effort to debunk myths and superstitions.
=500  \\$aTeatro crítico universal (1726–1739) is a multi-volume collection of essays that cover a range of subjects, from natural history and the then known sciences, education, history, religion, literature, philology, music, philosophy and medicine, down to superstitions, wonders and salient points of contemporary journalistic interest.

=008  220509s1711\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\s\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBurman, Pieter sr.$d1668-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q730541$924121
=245  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bWater, vande$c1711
=300  \\$a[xx]-32 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aidentical to 16B22f
=500  \\$aplea for the comedy
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696.  In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen. For example, he never missed an opportunity to denounce the clergy. In 1711, he took up arms against the theater-hostile Utrecht clergy. His "Speech for the Comedy," which first appeared in Latin, resulted in 13 pamphlets.
=500  \\$aSee also 07C33
=590  \\$aIn 't openbaer opgezegt by den aenvang zijner academische leszen, over den Toneeldichter Terentius. Op den 14 September 1711

=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C2_19_07C32$70$8RAR$91496$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C2$d2020-07-08$eKoopman$oKTS1 C2.19 07C32$p20138785$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO

=LDR  03141 a  a2200469   4500
=001  1497
=008  220509s1712\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBurman, Pieter sr.$d1668-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q730541$924121
=245  \\$aWederlegging van het zoogenaamde verweerschrift voor de Nederduitze Kerkenraad van Utrecht en het kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelykheid en schadelykheid der comedien;
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bWater, vande$c1712
=300  \\$a112 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aidentical to 16B22i
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696. In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen. For example, he never missed an opportunity to denounce the clergy. In 1711, he took up arms against the theater-hostile Utrecht clergy. His "Speech for the Comedy," which first appeared in Latin, resulted in 13 pamphlets. 
=500  \\$aSee also 07C32
=590  \\$at' Zamengesteld by Zes Utrechtze Predikanten, Nicolaus van Wingen, Abraham Josua Brakonier, Cornelius Boott, Aegidius vande Putt, Simon STratenus, Anthonius Driessen. Waar in, nevens hare lasterlyke en onware beschuldigingen, aangewezen worden haar gevaarlyke gronden, ontrent de Regeringe, en bedieninge des Godsdienst.
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aReligion$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q9174$93062
=650  \0$aTheater criticism$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2416230$921632

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBurman, Pieter sr.$d1668-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q730541$924121
=245  \\$aTweede wederlegginge van het antwoord van de vier Utrechtze predikanten$nvol.1
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bAppels$c1712
=300  \\$a[ii]-74 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aIdentical to 16B22
=500  \\$aSee also 07C32 and 07C33
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696. In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen. For example, he never missed an opportunity to denounce the clergy. In 1711, he took up arms against the theater-hostile Utrecht clergy. His "Speech for the Comedy," which first appeared in Latin, resulted in 13 pamphlets. 
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aReligion$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q9174$93062

=041  \\$adut$hlat
=100  \\$aBurman, Pieter sr.$d1668-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q730541$924121
=245  \\$aRedenvoering tegen de beschavende geleertheid.$bGedaan den viii.. Febr. 1720 overgezet door Dirk Smout
=260  \\$aLeiden$bLuchtmans$c1720
=300  \\$a[xxviii]-59 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aSatirical speech, in which the Leiden professor Burman summons the students not to tire themselves with Latin and Greek, "those studies, which falsely carry the name of civilizing, and which are so harmful to piety, good name, scholarship and the coffers".
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696. In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen.

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aCrane, Johan de$d1676-1746$4aut$96092
=245  \\$aAf-scheyd en bevesting reden over Hand. 20. vs. 26. 27. 28
=260  \\$aMiddelburg$bSchryver$c1728
=300  \\$a[vi]-112 pages
=336  \\$aprinted
=500  \\$aJohan de Crane belonged to a not inconsiderable family, that flourished for a long time in Zeeland. He was born February 23rd 1676, and after good school and academy education, on March 13th 1696 became a minister, he was called to Nisse, and confirmed there April 7th 1697, from where he left for Oostkapelle in 1703. His health forced him to ask for an honorable resignation in 1727, which was granted. After that time he lived in Middelburg, but still frequently visited the pulpit, both there and in his last congregation; he even had the rare privilege of being able to confirm his six successors in Oostkapelle over a period of nineteen years. He died in Middelburg on the 31st of December 1746.

=245  \\$aOverture to the Deserter, with Tunes for the Harpsichord or Forte Piano

=500  \\$aDomenico Corri (1746-1825), a native Roman, moved to Edinburgh in 1771 where he founded a publishing company and led the Vauxhall Pleasure Gardens.
=534  \\$a'Le Déserteur' (The Deserter) is an opéra comique by the French composer Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny with a libretto by Michel-Jean Sedaine. It was first performed on 6 March 1769 by the Comédie-Italienne at their public theatre, the Hôtel de Bourgogne in Paris.

=300  \\$a5 pages
=500  \\$aJean Théodore Latour (1766–1837) was a French pianist and composer. He wrote several piano sonatinas that have been adapted for early intermediate piano students. His work appears in several books designed for such students. Latour was appointed official pianist to the Prince Regent, later King George IV of the United Kingdom.

=008  210224s1780\\\\\\\||a||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=040  \\$aBF
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGluck, Christoph Willibald$d1714-1787$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q130759$96111
=245  \\$aIphigénie en Tauride.$bTragédie en quatre actes
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bDeslauriers$c1780
=300  \\$a[i]-211 pages
=500  \\$aWith Iphigénie, Gluck took his operatic reform to its logical conclusion. The recitatives are shorter and they are récitatif accompagné (i.e. the strings and perhaps other instruments are playing, not just continuo accompaniment). The normal dance movements that one finds in the French tragédie en musique are almost entirely absent. The drama is ultimately based on the play Iphigenia in Tauris by the ancient Greek dramatist Euripides which deals with stories concerning the family of Agamemnon in the aftermath of the Trojan War.
=610  \0$aOpéra (Paris, France)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q283339$920898
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aOpera$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1344$92468
=651  \0$aParis (France)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q90$9160
=700  \\$4lbt$aGuillard, Nicolas François$d1752-1814$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3339962$94760
